tool storage



STROL-120 is an integrated tool and hardware storage system that I designed, prototyped and constructed over the course of a semester with Danica Mitchell, Patricia Dranoff, and Connor Lynch. The system was designed to accommodate a new makerspace at Brown University. Though my (making) focus has shifted starkly to digital design, this project provided me a valuable foundation in design research.

industrial design / design research / makerspace / system design

coursework / group

fall 2014

Tasked with 'Building a Makerspace' in RISD course of the same title.

My responsibilities in the project were primarily system design and design research.

Moving elements in STROL-120 enable students to work on projects without having to lug around tools, and fixed elements ensure that certain tools are available for use at all times. Additionally, the 120 degree angle (Y-shape) in our moving unit allows multiple groups/students to work on the same cart.

FEATURES

Moving elements in STROL-120 enable students to work on projects without having to lug around tools, and fixed elements ensure that certain tools are available for use at all times. Additionally, the 120 degree angle (Y-shape) in our moving unit allows multiple groups/students to work on the same cart.

We explored a number of ideas on paper, and used rapid prototyping methods to experiment with different solutions. Field research (observing students work in the space through time-lapse videos) led us to conclude thatmobile and fixed components are needed to allow for different scopes of projects. Since the Brown Design Workshop is still being built, adaptability is crucial to ensure that the project stays relevant and useful.
